title: If I were to cover a song, can I legally put it on my album that I don’t plan to sell? - Quora

response.answer_text: Legally can be a tricky term. 8 D I’m no lawyer, I should be clear about that, but it seems to me you need to ask yourself three questions. A) Will anyone even notice? I mean, you’re not planning on selling the album… and even if you were, do you think it would sell enough that Adam Levine or Billie Eilish (or whoever… Costi or Maxim Fadeev… I don’t know where you live) would even notice? B) Will anyone even care? I mean, sure… if BTS stole a song from EXO, that would be a big deal. But if you just want to pay tribute to an artist you love and don’t make any money off it, what’s the harm? That’s why few (if any) major artists care when people remix their songs for Youtube. It’s free publicity and doesn’t take anything away from their actual sales. Unless you think more people will want to listen to your version of WAP than the official version. That’s also (I imagine) how most bands get away with performing cover songs in concerts. It’s simply not worth the effort to try to keep track of every band who ends their set with Kick Out the Jams, determine what portion of the ticket sales could be regarded as profit from that one song, try to collect the money… it would cost more in lawyer fees than it’s worth. C) What’s the worst that will happen? Suppose Arijit Singh did notice that you covered one of his songs on your album and suppose he took it as a personal affront. What can he do? His lawyer will send you a “cease and desist” letter and ask for fair recompense for usage, based on your sales. (This is the part where “I’m not a lawyer” is relevant.) If your album has no sales, his client will be due exactly X% of zero dollars. The worst that can happen is that you have to stop using that song on future editions of the album and not give away any more copies. I suppose there is a 4th question you could ask. Do you really care if it is legal or not? Because technically, it might be “illegal” but if no one cares, why should you? No harm, no foul. I happen to come from a family of artists… two musicians, two authors… and we’ve long since learned not to stress over this stuff unless it’s on a serious platform and we’re using a known name, or if we expect to make money off the endeavor. But even if you do expect to make a little money, do you really think Lady Gaga is going to get pissy over what small sales you might expect to have, considering how much money she has? Unless you’re a well know industry artist (in which case you wouldn’t have needed to ask this question) I think it’s a fair bet to assume you’re below Lady Gaga’s radar. 8 ) Peace be with you, my friend!

Maybe. Telling us what you don’t plan to do with it does not tell us what you do plan to do with it. If you plan to distribute it to the public or perform it in public, then you are required to pay the legal royalty, even if you are not making any money off it yourself. If, say, you intend to record the album and only play it at your own house, for small numbers of guests, then sure. Or if you’re only going to play it at licensed venues, where the venue would be required to pay the royalties. If, though, you intend to let people download it, then you have to pay the royalty to be legal.
